description: From Middle English ruffelen, perhaps from Old Norse hrufla (“to graze, scratch”) or Middle Low German ruffelen (“to wrinkle, curl”). Further origin unknown. Related to Middle Dutch ruyffelen, German Low German ruffeln. See English ruff.

entries.meaning: Any gathered or curled strip of fabric added as trim or decoration.
examples: She loved the dress with the lace ruffle at the hem.
to put the mind in a ruffle

entries.meaning: (military) A low, vibrating beat of a drum, quieter than a roll; a ruff.
(zoology) The connected series of large egg capsules, or oothecae, of several species of American marine gastropods of the genus Fulgur.

verbs.description: ruffle (third-person singular simple present ruffles, present participle ruffling, simple past and past participle ruffled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a ruffle in; to curl or flute, as an edge of fabric.
examples: Ruffle the end of the cuff.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To disturb; especially, to cause to flutter.
examples: Her sudden volley of insults ruffled his composure.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To grow rough, boisterous, or turbulent.
(intransitive) To become disordered; to play loosely; to flutter.
(intransitive) To be rough; to jar; to be in contention; hence, to put on airs; to swagger.
To make into a ruff; to draw or contract into puckers, plaits, or folds; to wrinkle.
To erect in a ruff, as feathers.
(military) To beat with the ruff or ruffle, as a drum.
To throw together in a disorderly manner.
